facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 676 and 677 of 1962 were filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 676 and 677 of 1962. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 2,7. 1960 of the Life

facts.text: Appeals against judgment and order dated February 27, 1960 of the Life Insurance Tribunal, Nagpur in Case No. 30 XII of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: from the judgment and order dated February 2,7. 1960 of the Life Insurance Tribunal, Nagpur in Case No. 30 XII of 1959. P. Malhotra, Hamendra K. Shah, .1. B. Dadachanji,

facts.text: Life Insurance Corporation of India applied under s.15 of LIC Act to Tribunal against Vishwabharti Insurance Company and directors for Rs.82,000 plus 6% interest from September 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: proceedings on an application by the Life Insurance Corporation of India  hereinafter called the Corporation  under s. 15 of the Life Insurance Corporation Act, 1956  Act XXXI of 1956 , shortly termed as the LIC Act, for ordering the Vishwabharti Insurance Company, Bombay. Damji Valji Shah and Jayantilal Hirijibhai Chawda, appellants in the C.A. 676 of 1962, Ghanshyamdas, appellant in C.A. 677 of 1962, the aforementioned individuals being directors of the Vishwabharti Insurance Company, and another director, to pay to the Corporation jointly and severally the sum of Rs. 82,000/- together with interest there at 6 per annum from September 1, 1956, till full payment.

facts.text: Vishwabharti Insurance Company was a composite insurer carrying life and other insurance business.

anchor.surface_text: The facts of the case briefly are these. The companypany was a companyposite insurer. i.e., an insurer who carried on. in addition to life insurance business. other classes of-insurance business.

facts.text: LIC Act came into force on July 1, 1956; Corporation established on September 1, 1956, the appointed day.

anchor.surface_text: The LIC Act came into force on july 1. 1956 and the Corporation was established on September 1. 1956 which was the appointed day according to s. 2 1  of that Act.

facts.text: On September 1, 1956, all assets and liabilities of life insurance business transferred to Corporation per s.7 LIC Act.

anchor.surface_text: On that day. in view of s. 7. all the assets and liabilities appertaining to the life insurance business  called the companytrolled business, vide s. 2 3   of the Company stood transferred to and vested in the Corporation.

facts.text: Rs.1,10,000 transferred from General Department to Life Department by resolution dated December 18, 1948 as advance, no interest, repay only from valuation surplus.

anchor.surface_text: By resolution dated December 18, 1948. Rs. 1.10.000/- were transferred from the General Department to the Life Department as advance to the Life Department Revenue Account for being added to the Life Fund. subject to the companydition that the Life Department would number be liable to pay any interest thereon and that numberrepayment of the lcan would be made except out of the valuation surplus of the Life Department.

facts.text: First actuarial valuation report for 1944-48 dated July 18, 1949: net liability Rs.6,55,718; Life Fund Rs.6,57,450; surplus Rs.1,732.

anchor.surface_text: The first actuarial valuation report of the companypany for the year 1944 -48. dated July 18 1949, showed that the net liability of the companypany was Rs. 6,55,7 18/and that the amount in the Life Fund was Rs. 6,57,450/and therefore the fund showed a surplus of Rs. 1,732/- over the net liabilities.

facts.text: Rs.60,000 out of Rs.1,10,000 written off in Profit Loss Appropriation Account for 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The Profit Loss Appropriation Account for the year 1949 shows that Rs. 60,000/- out of this amount of Rs. 1,10,000/- was written off as the companypany had made profits.

facts.text: Rs.32,000 transferred from General to Life Fund with retrospective effect from December 31, 1952 per resolution August 20, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Rs. 32,000/- were again similarly transferred to the Life Fund from the General Department with retrospective effect from December 31, 1952 in order to strengthen the position of the Life Fund. The second actuarial valuation report for the period 1949-52, dated September 9, 1953, showed that the policy liability amounted to Rs. 15,3,3,068, that the Life Fund stood at Rs. 15,35,890/- and that thus the Life Fund exceeded the net liability by Rs. 2,822/-.

facts.text: Second actuarial valuation 1949-52 dated September 9, 1953: policy liability Rs.15,33,068; Life Fund Rs.15,35,890; surplus Rs.2,822.

anchor.surface_text: dated September 9, 1953, showed that the policy liability amounted to Rs. 15,3,3,068, that the Life Fund stood at Rs. 15,35,890/- and that thus the Life Fund exceeded the net liability by Rs. 2,822/-

facts.text: Rs.82,000 transferred from Life Fund to General Department by resolution dated January 6, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: It was this amount of Rs. 82,000/- Rs. 50,000,- plus Rs. 32,000/-  which, by a resolution dated January 6. 1956 was transferred to the General Department from the Life Fund. The resolution reads Resolved that a loan of Rs. 82,000/-  eighty two thousand only  advanced to Life Department Revenue Account by General Department be and is hereby repaid to Genera1 Department

facts.text: Resolution of January 6, 1956 confirmed by Board on February 6, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: This resolution was companyfirmed by the Board of Directors at its meeting dated February 6, 1956.

facts.text: Life Insurance Emergency Provisions Ordinance, 1956 promulgated January 19, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: On January 19, 1956, the Life Insurance  Emergency Provisions  Ordinance, 1956  Ord. No. 1 of 1956  was promulgated by the President.

facts.text: Vishwabharti Insurance Company ordered to be wound up by Bombay High Court on November 9, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: the companypany having been ordered to be wound-up by the High Court on November 9, 1959,

facts.text: Tribunal decreed Rs.82,000 plus interest against company and directors 1 to 4 jointly and severally.

anchor.surface_text: It therefore decreed the suit and ordered the companypany and the directors, respondents 1 to 4, to pay to. the Corporation jointly and severally a sum of Rs. 82,000/- together with interest thereon at 6 per cent per annum from September 1, 1956 till full payment.

facts.text: Directors claimed Rs.82,000 transfer was repayment of loan from surplus per actuary report July 25, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: the appellants before us, companytested the claim of the Corporation and justified the transfer of Rs. 82,000/- to the General Department from the Life Fund on the ground that the amount had been lent by the General Department to the Life Department and had been paid back to the General Department by transfer from the Life Fund when the LifE Fund showed surplus, according to the report of the Actuary dated July 25, 1955.

facts.text: Tribunal held transfers of Rs.1,10,000 and Rs.32,000 not loans; Rs.82,000 transfer without consideration, not prudent.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal held that the amounts of Rs. 1,10,000/- and Rs. 30,000/- were number advanced to the Life Department as loans and that the transfer of Rs. 82.000/- was number out of the valuation surplus and that therefore the transfer of this amount companyld number be said to be for companysideration and necessary or reasonably necessary for the purpose of the companytrolled business of the companypany or even a prudent transaction having regard to the interest of the life policy holders.

facts.text: Supreme Court agreed transfers not loans; Rs.82,000 belonged to life business, vested in Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the Tribunal took a companyrect view about the nature of the transfer of Rs. 1,10,000/- in 1948 and Rs. 32,000/- in 1952 to the Life Insurance Fund and rightly held that the transfer of Rs. 82,000/- to the General Department by resolution dated January 6, 1956, was number in accordance with the provisions of the Insurance Act and that companysequently that amount companytinued to form part of the assets of the life insurance business of the companypany upto September 1, 1956 and that as such vested in the Corporation

facts.text: Actuary letter July 25, 1955 showed surplus Rs.1,12,033 including Rs.53,300 appreciation; net working surplus Rs.58,733.

anchor.surface_text: Reliance in this companynection is placed on behalf of the appellants on the letter of the actuary dated July 25, 1955. The actuary states On the above basis, the valuation shows a policy liability of Rs. 20,20,421. The Life Insurance Fund is Rs. 21,32,455. Thus there is a surplus of Rs. 1.12.033. The surplus includes Rs. 53,300 being the amount of appreciation on investments taken into account by you in the past two years. Thus the net working surplus is Rs. 58,733/-.

facts.text: Tribunal had jurisdiction despite winding up; s.446 Companies Act and s.44 LIC Act do not bar.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the Tribunal had jurisdiction to companytinue the proceedings after November 9, 1959 when the companypany was ordered to be wound-up and that the provisions of s. 446, Companies Act, or s. 44 a , LIC Act, do number in any way affect its jurisdiction to companytinue the proceedings.

issues.text: Whether the Tribunal had jurisdiction to proceed with the proceedings on the petition presented by the Corporation without the leave of the High Court in view of s. 446 of the Companies Act, 1956?

anchor.surface_text: i  The Tribunal had numberjurisdiction to proceed with the proceedings on the petition presented by the Corporation without the leave of the High Court in view of s. 446 of the Companies Act, 1956, the companypany having been ordered to be wound-up by the High Court on November 9, 1959,

issues.text: Whether, in view of s. 44(a) of the LIC Act, none of the provisions of the Act applied to the company and therefore the Tribunal could not proceed on the application of the Corporation subsequent to the company being wound-up?

anchor.surface_text: ii  In view of s. 44 a  of the LIC Act numbere of the provisions of the Act applied to the companypany and therefore the Tribunal companyld number proceed on the application of the Corporation subsequent to the companypany being wound-up.

issues.text: Whether the transfer of Rs. 82,000/- from the Life Fund to the General Department of the company was for consideration and was necessary for the life insurance business?

anchor.surface_text: iii  The transfer of Rs. 82,000/- from the Life Fund to the General Department of the companypany was for companysideration and was necessary for the life insurance business.

anchor.surface_text: It held that no leave of the Bombay High Court was necessary for proceeding with the petition and that the petition was maintainable and that s. 44 of the LIC Act did not bar the applicability of the provisions of the Act to the respondent company.

anchor.surface_text: In this connection, reference may be made to s. 41 of the LIC Act which provides that no civil Court shall have jurisdiction to entertain or adjudicate upon any matter which a Tribunal is empowered to decide or determine under that Act.

arguments.claim: LIC Act as special Act overrides Companies Act as general Act

anchor.surface_text: Further, the provisions of the special Act i.e, the LIC Act, will over-ride the provisions of the general Act viz., the Companies Act which is an Act relating to companies in general.

arguments.claim: s.44(a) LIC Act inapplicable as company not in winding up when Act came into force and not 'insurer' post-transfer

anchor.surface_text: The question of the applicability of the Act to a particular insurer is to be considered in relation to facts existing when the Act came into force. ... The company was not being wound-up under orders of the Court on July 1, 1956 ... On November 9, 1959 ... it was not an insurer ... as the company did not carry on life insurance business in India on that date.

arguments.claim: Transfers of Rs.1,10,000 and Rs.32,000 were not loans but deposits to augment Life Fund per s.10 Insurance Act

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the Tribunal that the amounts of Rs. 1.10,000/-and Rs. 32,000/- were not lent to the Life Department as such by the General Department. No question of lending money by one department of the company to the other can be ordinarily contemplated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.41 LIC Act excludes civil court jurisdiction including company court under s.446 Companies Act; special Act overrides general Act.

holdings.text: s.44(a) of the LIC Act does not bar the Tribunal's jurisdiction as the company was not being wound-up when the Act came into force and was not an insurer on the winding-up date.

anchor.surface_text: The question of the applicability of the Act to a particular insurer is to be considered in relation to facts existing when the Act came into force. ... anchor.surface_text: Further, the provisions of the special Act i.e, the LIC Act, will over-ride the provisions of the general Act viz., the Companies Act which is an Act relating to companies in general.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the Tribunal that the amounts of Rs. 1.10,000/-and Rs. 32,000/- were number lent to the Life Department as such by the General Department. No question of lending money by one department of the companypany to the other can be ordinarily companytemplated.

holdings.text: The Tribunal took a correct view about the nature of the transfer of Rs. 1,10,000/- in 1948 and Rs. 32,000/- in 1952 to the Life Insurance Fund and rightly held that the transfer of Rs. 82,000/- to the General Department by resolution dated January 6, 1956, was not in accordance with the provisions of the Insurance Act and that consequently that amount continued to form part of the assets of the life insurance business of the company upto September 1, 1956 and that as such vested in the Corporation.

holdings.text: The expression 'valuation surplus' has a technical meaning under the Act: it is the surplus disclosed in Form I of the Fourth Schedule to the Insurance Act following s.13 actuarial investigation.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Defined per statutory scheme of s.13 Insurance Act and Fourth Schedule Forms G,H,I.

holdings.text: No such actuarial valuation was made by the actuary prior to the transfer of Rs. 82,000/-; the letter dated July 25, 1955 does not constitute a proper s.13 valuation as no Form I abstract submitted to Controller; even per letter, net working surplus Rs.58,733 insufficient.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the Tribunal had jurisdiction to continue the proceedings after November 9, 1959 when the companypany was ordered to be wound-up and that the provisions of s. 446, Companies Act, or s. 44 a , LIC Act, do number in any way affect its jurisdiction to companytinue the proceedings.

We are therefore of opinion that the Tribunal took a correct view about the nature of the transfer of Rs. 1,10,000/- in 1948 and Rs. 32,000/- in 1952 to the Life Insurance Fund and rightly held that the transfer of Rs. 82,000/- to the General Department by resolution dated January 6, 1956, was not in accordance with the provisions of the Insurance Act and that consequently that amount continued to form part

anchor.surface_text: The question of the applicability of the Act to a particular insurer is to be considered in relation to facts existing when the Act came into force. ... The company was not being wound-up under orders of the Court on July 1, 1956 ... On November 9, 1959 ... it was not an insurer ... as the company did not carry on life insurance business in India on that date.

We are therefore of opinion that the Tribunal took a correct view about the nature of the transfer of Rs. 1,10,000/- in 1948 and Rs. 32,000/- in 1952 to the Life Insurance Fund and rightly held that the transfer of Rs. 82,000/- to the General Department by resolution dated January 6, 1956, was not in accordance with the provisions of the Insurance Act and that consequently that amount continued to form part
